awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Faunal Composition, Provinciality and Paleobiolgy of a Late Cretaceous Arctic Vertebrate Assemblage Revealed Through Cross-Latitudinal Comparisons
awd_abstract_narration:
The 70-million year old Prince Creek Formation of Arctic Alaska provides fossil evidence that a surprisingly diverse array of dinosaurs, birds, flying reptiles and small mammals lived in polar forests characterized by warm summers and five- to six-months of darkness and snowfall during the polar winter. Enduring these seasonally intense and variable conditions makes these animals uniquely suited to test major paleobiological questions pertaining to physiology, migration, body size changes, ecology and distribution. This project will examine these questions through new Arctic specimen collections and identifications, temperature determinations and growth studies, and comparison to findings with animals living at warmer lower latitudes. This project will bring together a diverse team of scientists who will share new ideas and methodologies and contribute to the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students. Results will be disseminated in scientific venues and presented publicly through museum exhibitions and K-12 presentations. The latter will include visits to rural, northern Alaskan schools to provide underserved Alaska Native students and teachers with an opportunity to learn about the fossils in their area and interact with NSF-sponsored researchers. 

Using macro- and microfossil remains, this study will establish a comprehensive dataset on the faunal composition of a Mesozoic polar assemblage, including descriptions of probable new species unique to the Arctic. Statistical techniques will be used to compare the faunal compositions between mid- and high latitudes to understand North American distribution patterns. Histological analyses of bones and teeth will provide the first rigorous testing of the affects of polar environments on the growth and physiology of dinosaurs and mammals. Lastly, a novel technique using biomarkers will be used to provide more precise paleotemperature estimates to understand the temperature regime experienced by the polar fauna.

por.por_cntn:
We conducted a comprehensive study comparing the entire vertebrate fauna of the Arctic Prince Creek Formation (PCF) of Alaska to that of the coeval Horseshoe Canyon Formation (HCF) of Alberta, Canada. This natural experiment represents the first comparative analysis of an entire polar vertebrate assemblage (animals that experienced extreme cold conditions and 4-5 months of polar darkness unexpected of reptiles) to a temporally equivalent, warm climate lower latitude assemblage. Our objectives were to test hypotheses regarding the physiology, provinciality and size changes in Cretaceous Period polar vertebrates.

Our results show that: 1) the dinosaurs from the PCF are unique to the Arctic (all appear to be new species, several of which we have named and several are about to be announced) and represent a ?Lost World? of polar-adapted reptiles; 2) the mammals, birds and fish recovered are also unique to the Arctic (one marsupial mammal has been described and several more mammals and fish will soon be described); 3) because no terrestrial ectotherms (cold-blooded animals) such as crocodiles, turtles and lizards have been recovered it provides some of the most compelling evidence that, like the mammals and birds, dinosaurs were warm-blooded; 4) our discovery of embryonic and hatching dinosaurs in the Arctic, coupled with the slow incubation times of dinosaurian eggs and analyses showing that dinosaurian growth was unaffected by the cold-conditions, shows these animals were year-round polar denizens. This opens up fascinating new questions regarding how they endured the adverse climatic conditions where limited energetic resources were available in the winter; finally 5) analyses of soil lipid biommarkers and volcanic ashes have helped us to refine the climatic conditions that the PCF community experienced and the temporal window when these animals actually existed.

This NSF-funded project led to publications and presentations to professional audiences and the lay public, thereby facilitating scientific advancement and contributed to a more scientifically literate society. Involvement of undergraduates and graduate students in the research has enabled them to launch their own careers in science. Public dissemination to k-12 and collegiate audiences, and an internationally vetted scientific documentary facilitated introduction of both field and laboratory scientific hypothesis testing to the masses.
